decision_conditions: The development to which this permission relates shall be commenced within three years of the granting of the original permission ref 19/01931/FUL.Reason: This is required by Section 91 of the Town and Country Planning Act 1990 (as amended).

Samples for all facing materials, railings and staircase furniture shall be submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to above ground works. The development shall then be built in accordance with these approved samples and completed prior to occupation.Reason: To ensure a satisfactory appearance on completion of the development in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions)  and DM12 (Development in Conservation Areas and Affecting Heritage Assets) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

These facilities shall be fully implemented and made available for use prior to the occupation of the development hereby permitted and shall thereafter be retained for use at all times.Reason: To ensure the provision of satisfactory cycle storage facilities and in the interests of highway safety in accordance with Policy DM8 (Sustainable Transport for New Developments) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

All works on site shall take place in accordance with the following details which shall have previously been submitted to in the form of a Construction Management Plan and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority prior to the commencement of work:  (a) Statement on how the proposed development will be built, with method statements to outline how major elements of the works would be undertaken;(b) Proposals for loading/unloading materials, site storage etc;(c) The route to and away from site for muck away and vehicles with materials;(d) Deliveries/collections to and from the site should use a route that is agreed with NRSWA team. The agreed route should be signed accordingly.   (e) Protocol for managing deliveries to one vehicle at a time on sites with restricted access or space;(f) Protocol for managing vehicles that need to wait for access to the site; and(g) Whether any reversing manoeuvres are required onto or off the public highway into the site, and whether a banksman will be provided;(h) Temporary site access;(i) Signing system for works traffic; (j) Site access warning signs will be required in adjacent roads.(k) Whether it is anticipated that statutory undertaker connections will be required into the site.  (l) Storage of plant, materials and operatives vehicles;(m) Measures for the laying of dust, suppression of noise and abatement of other nuisance arising from development works;(n) Location of all ancillary site buildings;(o) Means of enclosure of the site; and(p) Wheel washing equipment.  (q) The parking of vehicles of site operatives and visitors.Reason: These details are required prior to commencement of development because the relevant works would take place at the beginning of the construction phase and in order to safeguard the amenities of the surrounding residential occupiers and to safeguard highway safety and the free flow of traffic in accordance with Policy DM10 (Design Requirements for New Developments including House Extensions) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

The hard surfaces hereby approved shall be made of porous materials and retained thereafter or provision shall be made and retained thereafter to direct run-off water from the hard surface to a permeable or porous area or surface within the curtilage of the property.Reason: To reduce the risk of flooding and pollution and increase the level of sustainability of the development and to comply with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Within 3 months of first occupation, evidence must be submitted to the Council confirming that the development hereby permitted has achieved no less than the C02 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes Level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the "Schedule of Evidence Required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 and WAT1 of the Code for Sustainable Homes Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105L/day must be submitted to the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.Reason:  In order to ensure that all development is designed and built to make the most efficient use of resources, reduce its lifecycle impact on the environment and contributes to climate change mitigation and adaptation in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the LDF Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Prior to above ground works and with specific regard to the proposed courtyard development, details of the implementation, adoption, maintenance and management of a sustainable drainage system shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the local planning authority.  The system shall be implemented prior to occupation and thereafter managed and maintained in accordance with the approved details.  Those details shall include a timetable for its implementation, and a management and maintenance plan for the lifetime of the development which shall include the arrangements for adoption by any public body or statutory undertaker, or any other arrangements to secure the effective operation of the sustainable drainage system throughout its lifetime.Reason: To prevent the increased risk of flooding in accordance with Policy CS1 (Climate Change Mitigation) of the Local Development Framework Core Strategy Adopted April 2012.

Application SiteThe site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.ProposalErection of single-storey rear extension with associated changes to fenestrationConsultationSix Neighbouring properties have been notified and no representations have been received.AssessmentThe key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.- Fire SafetyDesignPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The principal properties to be considered in relation to neighbouring amenity are No. 40 and No. 44 Cleveland Road. Both properties benefit from rear extensions. Due to the limited depth of approximately 2.4m, It is considered that the proposed development would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy. Officers note the proposed windows on the ground floor side elevation but consider the existing boundary treatment sufficient to protect privacy.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has submitted a Fire Safety Strategy.  Officers are satisfied that the proposal adequately meets the requirements of Policy D12(A). Ongoing compliance with the strategy would be secured through conditions, in the event of a favourable recommendation.ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

SiteThe application site is the ground floor unit of the three-storey mid-terrace building No. 8 Victoria Road, Surbiton. The application site is part of the Grade II listed 2-8 Victoria Road, which is a mid/late 19th century rendered terrace of 7 shops with two floors of accommodation above, including a pediment above each central window at first floor and a decorated parapet. The character of the terrace is one of architectural unity with distinctive fenestration (6 panel windows of which the lower 4 are casements at first floor, 9 panel second floor sliding-sash windows and interesting and coherent detailing including pronounced window reveals, cills and cill-supports, timber shadow panels and a continuous bracketed and corberlled parapet. The ground floor shops display a variety of design approaches but have a consistency in general dimensions of frontage, fascia and projecting sign.The application site is within the Surbiton Town Centre Conservation Area, as well as the Surbiton District Centre Inset Area. Furthermore other listed buildings are located nearby, including no. 12 Victoria Road (Grade II) immediately to the West of the building, and Surbiton Station (Grade II) approximately 60m from the site.Planning History 22/00442/ADV - Display of 1 no externally illuminated fascia sign and 1no projection hanging sign. Application Granted with Conditions. 22/00439/LBC - Internal and external (including shopfront) alterations and associated works. Application Granted with Conditions. 22/01139/FUL - Installation of 2no. new external plant units and acoustic screens at 2nd floor level, HVAC pipework and air intake luvre grilles at 1st floor level and associated works. Pending consideration. Consultations41 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received. Historic England - No comments. Environmental Health Officer - No objection subject to planning condition.Heritage and Conservation - Concern regarding the installation of acoustic screens around the external plant at second floor level. From an aesthetic point of view (whilst acknowledging that they are unlikely to be seen from street level), as well as functional and long-term sustainable point of view.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets. The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the installation of two new external plant units at second floor level, installation of HVAC pipework through the flat roof at first floor level, as well as the installation of extract and air intake louvre grilles in rear wall to lightwell at first floor level. These works would be largely unviewable from the streetscene, sited to the rear of the building, and are appropriate additions to a structure in commercial use. Officers therefore consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the building and surrounding area.  Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The HVAC pipework riser would be attached to the exterior of the building, exiting through the flat roof of the first floor level and rising to the HVAC plant on the roof of the second floor. This pipework would be in direct view of a first floor window of the adjoining property at No. 9 Victoria Road. This would result in some visual intrusion to the window of this property. However, in conjunction with the proposed scale and design of the pipework, as the pipework would be situated approximately 1.8 metres away from this window Officers consider that the proposal would not result in a significantly detrimental impact on the neighbouring property at No. 9 Victoria Road through visual intrusion or loss of outlook. Through the installation of plant machinery and associated elements, the impact the proposal would have on neighbouring properties through the creation of noise is a key factor to consider. The application has been supported by an Acoustic Assessment which indicates that the calculated rating level for the new plant is approximately 6dB below the measured background sound level, which meets the requirements of Kingston Council to be 5dB lower than measured background noise. Furthermore, this application has been reviewed by the Environmental Health Officer, who did not object to the proposal. As such Officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the amenity of neighbouring properties.  Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements. When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Officers Comments: As it is considered that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the structure, would not result in a significant loss of historic fabric, and that the development would not be viewable from the streetscene, Officers consider that the proposal would not cause harm to the cultural significance of the Surbiton Town Centre Conservation Area or the Grade II listed building 2-8 Victoria Road.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Condition 3Condition 3 reads as follows:The development hereby approved shall not be occupied until the alterations to the access road detailed on Drawing No. TSP/GRA/P2631/002 Rev. E have been fully completed and details of the completion have been submitted to and acknowledged in writing by the Local Planning Authority.  In the event the works detailed on drawing no. TSP/GRA/P2631/002 Rev. E are not able to be fully completed, prior to the occupation of the development each flat shall be fitted with a sprinkler system., in accordance with a scheme that has been previously submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.The applicant has submitted drawing number TSP/GRA/P2631 002 Rev. E and photos of the completed works. The Council's Neighbourhood Traffic Engineer has confirmed that the details are acceptable as this is privately maintained land. As such, this condition can be discharged in full.Condition 4Condition 4 reads as follows:The development should be designed to comply with Secured by Design (SBD) principles, and unless otherwise agreed in writing by the Local Planning Authority, no part of the development hereby approved shall be used or occupied until details confirming full SBD accreditation has been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority.Details of doors and windows have been provided that, the applicant contends, met Secured by Design accreditation at the time the development was constructed.  Whilst the development was occupied prior to this condition being discharged, confirmation has since been received from the Secured by Design Officer that, on the basis of security measures that have been implemented, the condition can be discharged.  Therefore, whilst the condition has not been fully complied with, the intent of the condition has subsequently been satisfied and it would not be reasonable nor worthwhile to withhold the discharge of this condition. It is also noted that this condition was previously discharged for the original permission (15/16253/FUL) through 16/16625/COND.Condition 10Condition 10 reads:No part of the development hereby approved shall be occupied until evidence has been submitted to the Council confirming that the development has achieved not less than the CO2 reductions (ENE1), internal water usage (WAT1) standards equivalent to Code for Sustainable Homes level 4.  Evidence requirements are detailed in the 'Schedule of evidence required for Post Construction Stage from ENE1 & WAT1 of the Code of Sustainable Homes Technical Guide.  Evidence to demonstrate a 19% reduction compared to 2013 Part L regulations and internal water usage rates of 105l/p/day must be submitted to and approved by the Local Planning Authority, unless otherwise agreed in writing.An Energy Analysis has been submitted which demonstrates that a 25.11% reduction against 2013 Part L regulations is being achieved. SAP calculations have also been provided. These details were previously approved through 16/16625/COND (relating to the original permission - 15/16253/FUL) and considered acceptable.  It is also noted that this condition was previously discharged for the original permission (15/16253/FUL) through 16/16625/COND.No information with regards to Water Usage has been submitted, as such a condition would be imposed to secure this information Condition 12Condition 12 reads as follows:No fans, louvres, ducts or other external plant other than those shown on the drawings hereby approved shall be installed without the prior written approval of the Local Planning Authority.Drawings 15571 C 06 Rev. C, 15571 C 07 Rev. C, 15571 C 08 Rev. C and 15571 C 09 Rev. C and a photograph of the vents and piping as installed have been submitted. These details were previously approved through 16/16625/COND.The Council's Pollution Control Officer raises no objections and so this condition can be discharged. Condition 18Condition 18 reads as follows:The levels of buildings, roads, parking spaces and pathways within the site shall only be in accordance with details which have been previously submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority before development is commenced.Drawings 15571 C 00-3 Rev. A and 15571 C 00-4 Rev. A have been submitted which indicate the site levels in relation to surrounding land. Elevations of the building have been provided which clarify building levels in relation to the ground level. These details are considered sufficient to discharge this condition. Condition 20Condition 20 reads:The development shall be completed in accordance with the following details which shall have been submitted to and approved in writing by the Local Planning Authority, before building work commences.(a)	Samples of materials for all external finishes (including their colour and texture).(b)	Detailed cross sections through façade, and sample elevation to demonstrate brick work detailing (1:10).(c)	Boundary treatment (including walls, fences and gates).(d)	Treatment and layout of all parts of the site not covered by the approved buildings, including hard and soft landscaping.(e)	Refuse storage facilities.(f)	External and lighting.(g)	Sewer and drainage runs.(h)	Any external plant and equipment.Part a - Whilst no samples have been received, the building has been constructed and photos of the completed building (including brick and windows) and detailed drawings have been provided which demonstrate that the materials are of a reasonable quality and sympathetic to the surrounding area. The intent of the condition is therefore satisfied.Part b - Detailed cross section drawings have been provided through the building. These details are considered acceptable. The same comments apply in relation to brick samples as above but the detailed drawings and photos submitted show the brick detailing which are deemed acceptable. Part c - A site plan and detailed drawings of the boundary treatment have been submitted which are deemed acceptable. Part d - A site plan and a detailed plan of the car parking area have been provided which identify the paving to the car park area and soft landscaping surrounding the building. These details are considered acceptable. Part e - Details of the refuse enclosure have been provided. Part f - A site plan has been submitted and detailed specifications of the bollard lighting have been provided. Part g - A drainage plan has been received detailing the SuDS (attenuation tank) and pump details. Part h - details of bike storage for 12 no. bicycles has been submitted. This level of provision is consistent with the London Plan and the cycle storage is secure and sheltered (with the Met Police having confirmed that lockable doors have been installed to the cycle storage shed).In summary, whilst the development was commenced prior to this condition being discharged, satisfactory details have been provided (some of which were previously approved for the original application through 16/16625/COND). Therefore, whilst the condition has not been fully complied with, the intent of the condition has subsequently been satisfied and it would not be reasonable nor worthwhile to withhold the discharge of this condition. Condition 21Condition 21 reads as follows:Details of sustainable urban drainage system in accordance with the sustainable drainage hierarchy set out in policy 5.13 of the London Plan Consolidated Alterations since 2011 (March 2015) shall be submitted to and approved in writing prior to commencement of development.The Council's Lead Local Flood Officer has confirmed the drainage details submitted (attenuation tank and sump pump) are satisfactory.SummaryFor the reasons set out above, the above conditions can be discharged in full subjectto the imposition of a condition regarding Water Useage

Thames Water advise that A Groundwater Risk Management Permit from Thames Water will be required for discharging groundwater into a public sewer. Any discharge made without a permit is deemed illegal and may result in prosecution under the provisions of the Water Industry Act 1991. We would expect the developer to demonstrate what measures he will undertake to minimise groundwater discharges into the public sewer. Permit enquiries should be directed to Thames Water's Risk Management Team by telephoning 020 3577 9483 or by emailing trade.effluent@thameswater.co.uk . Application forms should be completed on line via www.thameswater.co.uk. Please refer to the Wholsesale; Business customers; Groundwater discharges section.Thames Water will aim to provide customers with a minimum pressure of 10m head (approx 1 bar) and a flow rate of 9 litres/minute at the point where it leaves Thames Waters pipes. The developer should take account of this minimum pressure in the design of the proposed development.

The site comprises a detached dwelling.8x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development;- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings;- The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters. - Fire Safety Assessment. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: The proposed ground floor extension would project 4 metres to the rear, which exceeds policy guidelines. However, there is an existing extension to the rear of the closest neighbouring property at no. 13 Connaught Road. It is considered that the proposed development would not significantly affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.The side extension would be modest in height and would be in general accordance with the SPD. TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The proposal would involve the conversion of a garage into habitable space. However, the existing hardstanding to the front of the dwelling would be sufficient to accommodate one spaces for on-site parking. The PTAL for this part of Connaught Road, is 4. Taking into account the maximum car parking standards set out in the London Plan, which are up to 0.5 - 0.75 spaces per dwelling, for an Outer London PTAL 4, 1 to 3 and 3+ bedroom dwelling, it is considered that this issue would not warrant grounds for refusal, given that it is reflective of the existing situation.Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013)

The site comprises a semi-detached dwelling.12x neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations have been received.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The design of the proposed development; and, The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on highways and transportation matters.The impact of the development on flood risk and drainage. Fire Safety Assessment.When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Note: The application includes the erection of a part single, double-storey side extension. These extensions are sympathetically designed and respectful of the character and design of the Host Property and do not impact negatively on the wider setting or area.The proposed rear dormer roof extension, would not be set down from the ridge line of the original roof slope, would not be set in to the sides, or set up from the eaves, contrary to the recommendations set out in the Residential Design SPD. However, the proposed rear dormer would be similar to a dormer that could be erected within the permitted development rights for the Host Property and for this reason, given the credible fall-back position, Officers consider that the proposed dormer is considered acceptable. Officers also note that following the previous refusal the dormer has been reduced in size making it more acceptable.Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance. Officers Note: The proposed development would extend slightly further than the furthest projecting rear wall of no.3 Grosvenor Gardens and only slightly further than the rear wall of no.7 Grosvenor Gardens. For these reasons, no significant increase in the loss of daylight, sense of enclosure or loss of outlook to either of the adjoining properties in Grosvenor Gardens. The proposed rear roof dormer, would cause a slight loss of privacy to neighbouring properties. However the loss caused, would not be significant enough to warrant refusal.TransportationPolicy T6 of the London Plan 2021 states that car parking should be restricted in line with levels of existing and future public transport accessibility and connectivity. The maximum standards as set out in policies T6.1 to T6.5 should be applied to development proposals.Policy DM9, Policy DM10 and the Council's Sustainable Transport SPD 2013 together require development proposals to comply with the car parking standards in the London Plan.Officer Comment: The proposal would involve the conversion of a garage into habitable space. However, the existing hardstanding to the front of the dwelling would be sufficient to accommodate one spaces for on-site parking. The PTAL for this part of Grosvenor Gardens, is 1b. Taking into account the maximum car parking standards set out in the London Plan, which are up to 1.5 spaces per dwelling, for an Outer London PTAL 1 to 2, 3+ bedroom dwelling, it is considered that this issue would not warrant grounds for refusal, given that it is reflective of the existing situation.Flood Risk AssessmentThe application site falls within Flood Risk Zone 2 (medium probability). Consequently the Flood Risk Assessment: Standing Advice issued by the Environment Agency and DEFRA, 2012 must be applied. For minor extensions such as this it is essential that the proposed floor level is no lower than existing in order to mitigate future flood risk impacts. Officer Comment: The submitted flood risk assessment states that floor levels within the proposed development will be set no lower than existing levels and flood proofing of the proposed development has been incorporated where appropriate which is considered acceptable in this case and in compliance with policy SI12 of the London Plan 2021 and Policy DM4 of the LDF Core Strategy (2012).Fire Safety AssessmentLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer Comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development addresses the previous refusal, and would in its own right be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

SiteThe application site is the ground floor unit of the three-storey mid-terrace building No. 8 Victoria Road, Surbiton. The application site is part of the Grade II listed 2-8 Victoria Road, which is a mid/late 19th century rendered terrace of 7 shops with two floors of accommodation above, including a pediment above each central window at first floor and a decorated parapet. The character of the terrace is one of architectural unity with distinctive fenestration (6 panel windows of which the lower 4 are casements at first floor, 9 panel second floor sliding-sash windows and interesting and coherent detailing including pronounced window reveals, cills and cill-supports, timber shadow panels and a continuous bracketed and corberlled parapet. The ground floor shops display a variety of design approaches but have a consistency in general dimensions of frontage, fascia and projecting sign.The application site is within the Surbiton Town Centre Conservation Area, as well as the Surbiton District Centre Inset Area. Furthermore other listed buildings are located nearby, including no. 12 Victoria Road (Grade II) immediately to the West of the building, and Surbiton Station (Grade II) approximately 60m from the site.Planning History 22/00442/ADV - Display of 1 no externally illuminated fascia sign and 1no projection hanging sign. Application Granted with Conditions. 22/00439/LBC - Internal and external (including shopfront) alterations and associated works. Application Granted with Conditions. 22/01140/LBC - Installation of 2no. new external plant units and acoustic screens at 2nd floor level, HVAC pipework and air intake luvre grilles at 1st floor level and associated works. Pending consideration. Consultations41 neighbouring properties have been notified of the proposals and no representations were received. Historic England - No comments. Environmental Health Officer - No objection subject to planning condition.Heritage and Conservation - Concern regarding the installation of acoustic screens around the external plant at second floor level. From an aesthetic point of view (whilst acknowledging that they are unlikely to be seen from street level), as well as functional and long-term sustainable point of view.ConsiderationThe key areas of assessment are: The impact of the development on character and appearance. The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings.The impact of the development on heritage assets. The impact of the development on fire safety. When read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.Officers Comments: The application proposes the installation of two new external plant units at second floor level, installation of HVAC pipework through the flat roof at first floor level, as well as the installation of extract and air intake louvre grilles in rear wall to lightwell at first floor level. These works would be largely unviewable from the streetscene, sited to the rear of the building, and are appropriate additions to a structure in commercial use. Officers therefore consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the building and surrounding area.  Policy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officers Comments: The HVAC pipework riser would be attached to the exterior of the building, exiting through the flat roof of the first floor level and rising to the HVAC plant on the roof of the second floor. This pipework would be in direct view of a first floor window of the adjoining property at No. 9 Victoria Road. This would result in some visual intrusion to the window of this property. However, in conjunction with the proposed scale and design of the pipework, as the pipework would be situated approximately 1.8 metres away from this window Officers consider that the proposal would not result in a significantly detrimental impact on the neighbouring property at No. 9 Victoria Road through visual intrusion or loss of outlook. Through the installation of plant machinery and associated elements, the impact the proposal would have on neighbouring properties through the creation of noise is a key factor to consider. The application has been supported by an Acoustic Assessment which indicates that the calculated rating level for the new plant is approximately 6dB below the measured background sound level, which meets the requirements of Kingston Council to be 5dB lower than measured background noise. Furthermore, this application has been reviewed by the Environmental Health Officer, who did not object to the proposal. As such Officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the amenity of neighbouring properties.  Paragraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements. When considering the impact of a proposed development on the significance of a designated heritage asset, great weight should be given to the asset's conservation (and the more important the asset, the greater the weight should be). This is irrespective of whether any potential harm amounts to substantial harm, total loss or less than substantial harm to its significance. Section 72 of the Planning (Listed Buildings and Conservation Areas) Act 1990 (as amended) places a duty on local planning authorities to pay special attention to the desirability of preserving or enhancing the character and appearance of conservation areas, when considering development proposals that would affect land or buildings within them.Officers Comments: As it is considered that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the structure, would not result in a significant loss of historic fabric, and that the development would not be viewable from the streetscene, Officers consider that the proposal would not cause harm to the cultural significance of the Surbiton Town Centre Conservation Area or the Grade II listed building 2-8 Victoria Road.London Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, the plans include the provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.In conclusion, the proposed development would be in general accordance with the National Planning Policy Framework (2021), the National Planning Practice Guidance, the London Plan (2021), Policies of the Core Strategy (2012) and the Residential Design SPD (2013).

Application SiteThe site comprises a two storey semi-detached dwelling. The site is not subject to any land use designations or environmental constraintsProposalThe application seeks permission for demolition of existing rear lean to and erection of new porch, single-storey rear extension and first floor side extension with associated changes to fenestration. Hip to gable and rear dormer roof extension with installation 3no front rooflights to facilitate loft conversion.Consultations13 properties were notified of the proposal. Two representations were received objecting to the proposal on grounds including:Loss of privacy as a result of the Juliet balconyUse of render instead of brickNoise and general disturbance during constructionOffiers note: The proposed Juliet balcony has been removed and a condition would be imposed requiring the development to be rendered. Other matters raised which are not material planning considerations to be dealt with by building regulations and party wall legislation include:Project management of the jobOption to have boundary wall of neighbouring property renderedNo boundary wall shown along the shared boundary with No.43Revised drawings have been submitted subsequent to the initial submission and objections that include:- The patio has been reduced in height to no more than 30cm above ground level- The rear dormer has been reduced in scale, altering the layout to the loft and introduction of  a skylight to the rear instead of the Juliet balcony (raised as a concern in the objection)- The roof has been altered from a gable to a partial hipped roof to match No. 39 AssessmentThe main issues in the assessment of the application are:- The impact of the development on the character and appearance of the area;- The impact of the development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers.Character and AppearancePolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should enhance local context by delivering buildings and spaces that positively respond to local distinctiveness through their layout, orientation, scale, appearance and shape, with due regard to existing and emerging street hierarchy, building types, forms and proportions.Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 and the guidance in the Council's Residential Design Guide SPD 2013 require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area.The proposed front porch would have a modest projection from the front elevation, with a roof of an appropriate pitch and design. The porch would be finished in brick and utilise the existing porch windows and doors, with no impact to parking on site.The proposed ground floor extension would accord with the Residential Design SPD in terms of depth, and would be of an acceptable scale and design finish to match the host building. The extension would match the depth of the rear extension to the neighbouring property at No.39 Hemsby Road, and would be consistent with the overall pattern of single storey development within the surrounding area. The proposed first floor side extension would be setback from the front elevation, and the boundary in accordance with the SPD, with a roof form that reflects and relates well to the main house, and would appear a subordinate and proportionate addition to the property.  The rendered finish would be in keeping with both the application property and surrounding development. Fenestration details would also match the existing windows to the front elevation.Hip-to-gable roof extensions are not usually appropriate as they are often at odds with the existing character of a property. This may be particularly true when proposing to extend the roof of a semi-detached property, which would upset the visual balance of the two houses, particularly when viewed in the context of other houses in the street or wider area. In this instance, the proposed hip to gable roof would not alter this pair of semi-detached dwellinghouses, given the different roof form that exists to the neighbouring property at No.43 Hemsby Road and the proposed partial hip design would match that of No.349 Hemsby. Officers also note that there are a variety of roof forms and property types evident along Hemsby Road and there are examples, including some nearby to the application site. It is therefore considered on balance that the proposed hip to gable roof extension would not appear unduly different within, or be harmful to, the character and appearance of the application property, adjoining property or wider streetscene. The proposed rear dormer would be set down from the main roof, it would be appropriately set in from the sides of the roof slope and in from the eaves, and as such would appear as a proportionate addition to the host property. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the proposed development would have an acceptable impact on the character and appearance of the area in accordance with policy D3 of the London Plan 2021 and policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy D3 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should deliver appropriate outlook, privacy and amenity, and should help prevent or mitigate the impacts of noise and poor air quality.Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy also seeks to safeguard the amenities of neighbouring occupiers. To this end, it states that developments should have regard to the amenities of occupants and neighbours, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.The principal properties to consider are Nos.39 and 43 Hemsby Road. There are existing extensions at ground and first floor levels to both neighbouring properties and the proposed development would mostly align with these. To No.39 the properties are not attached. At ground floor the extension would be of an acceptable scale and depth and separated from the neighbouring property ensuring no loss of privacy, outlook daylight or sunlight. There are no habitable windows to the flank elevation of No.39 that would be affected by the first floor extension and those windows proposed to the flank elevation of the first floor extension will be obscured (secured by condition). There is an existing ground floor extension at No.43 Hemsby Road, and the proposed rear extension would not project beyond this. Given the siting, scale and design of the other proposed extensions, it is unlikely there would be any loss of amenities to occupants of No.43. Having regard to the above, officers consider that the impact of the proposed development on the amenities of neighbouring occupiers would be acceptable.Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.Officer comment: The applicant has not submitted a Fire Safety Strategy, however, there is sufficient space for provision of a suitably positioned outside space for fire appliances/ an evacuation assembly point and officers see no reason why a development of the type sought could not comply with the rest of the provisions of Policy D12(A), the details of which could be secured through conditions. For these reasons, officers conclude that the proposal would not conflict with Policy D12 of the London Plan.ConclusionThe representations received have been carefully considered, issues with regards to disturbance during construction are noted - however, it is to be acknowledged that any residential extension involves some general disturbance, if this passes into a nuisance (assuming the threshold is passed) the Environmental Health team of the Council has powers to intervene, no evidence has been submitted that would demonstrate that the proposed development would be uncharacteristically noises or cause uncharacteristic disturbance. Questions with regards to Project Management are not relevant to the planning process. Overall, it is concluded that the development would be in general accordance with the Development Plan.
